These are the wrenching questions families across our district face if President Trump succeeds in destroying the Affordable Care Act. I know I will be fighting for Keith’s family and all the families I met with today across our district.

What happens if the law goes away? Will the insurance company raise gouge Keith because of his son’s pre-existing condition? Will he be able to stay on his dad’s insurance at all? If the ACA is repealed Keith wonders: What happens to my son’s health care the next day?

Kyle has muscular dystrophy. It’s a tough disease -- and expensive to treat. Because the law allows young people to stay on their parents’ plans Kyle has been able to stay on his dad’s health insurance even as he headed off to college.

My last stop was an old friend: Keith in Howell. When the law allowing young adults to stay on their parents’ insurance to age 26 passed more than 2 million uninsured young people got coverage. Keith’s son is one. https://t.co/vNhLlyGPx7

She told me what it was like to see young people who got coverage through their parents' insurance and self-employed workers who used their new coverage to establish a relationship with a health care provider for the first time.

Julie Thomas-Beckett is a nurse practitioner in the Lansing area who remembers what it was like before protections for pre-existing conditions and other provisions of the ACA became law. https://t.co/vK7dOKIxqa

But those rules are threatened by the lawsuit now in front of the Supreme Court. If that lawsuit succeeds costs for these simple preventive health measures are likely to go up and the health of Robert’s patients to go down.

Those rules make it more likely his patients get things like annual checkups screenings for things like breast cancer even flu shots. It’s just one example of rules in place that lower costs and help us all stay healthy.

Robert Mavrogordato is a medical-surgical nurse in Lansing. At his practice patients get treated regardless of insurance status -- but he sees first-hand the importance of current protection that make preventive care free of out-of-pocket costs. https://t.co/VNoKQAT5gm

I know how hard cancer is on families -- and how much harder it will be for families like Mark’s if they lose protections for pre-existing conditions. Yet doing away with those protections is just what the Trump administration is arguing for in court.

When Mark changed jobs a few years later because of the protections currently in law he was able to get coverage for the family on the health care exchange. And Susan’s pre-existing condition wasn’t a roadblock to getting covered.

Mark Collatz of East Lansing is a good example of how events from years ago will take on new significance if the Supreme Court tosses out protections for pre-existing conditions. Mark’s wife Susan Loomis survived brain cancer several years ago. https://t.co/30GWMrWFMr

Every community in our district has neighbors like Kara and Elizabeth. The ACA’s protections are a safety net for their families but if the Trump administration’s lawsuit succeeds that safety net would disappear.

Elizabeth’s coverage comes from her husband’s employer. Without the ACA she knows that her husband’s insurance company could charge more for her care and that if they ever lost his insurance they’d struggle to find affordable coverage.

Under the ACA Kara can keep her kids on her coverage until age 26 -- a protection that goes away if the Supreme Court invalidates the ACA. She’s not sure how she’ll get coverage for their serious conditions without the ACA.

Next I stopped to talk to neighbors Kara Sprague and Elizabeth Kowal. Both Kara’s children have pre-existing conditions that would leave them exposed without ACA protections. Elizabeth herself has a pre-existing condition: diabetes. https://t.co/YdTdQQCvo5

First stop: Linda and Craig Brown of Clarkston. Their two sons have serious chronic health conditions and even with Craig's coverage they pay $40000 a year for insurance. Her husband is holding off on retiring to keep that insurance. https://t.co/YKPxv9s6ch

We’re on the road for our tour across the 8th District listening to constituents talk about what the Affordable Care Act means to them -- and what it would mean to lose the ACA. https://t.co/CS8dJeO4fm

I see Mom in all the people who come to me with their own stories. Tomorrow I’ll cross the district to talk to them about what’s at stake. I hope you’ll follow along. In the meantime read about the case and what it means. https://t.co/I7IGr9RGkY

This issue is personal for me. When my mom was diagnosed with the cancer that eventually took her life her coverage had lapsed. Insurance companies could charge her more because of a pre-existing condition.

Tomorrow we’ll be one month away from that hearing. And I’ll spend the day visiting people across the 8th District who are waiting and watching to find out if the coverage they depend on will be there when they need it.

Election Day is just 25 days away. But I’m looking at another date on the calendar: Nov. 10 one week after the election when the U.S. Supreme Court will hear arguments about a lawsuit that could dismantle the Affordable Care Act and threaten health coverage for millions.

We’ve mourned infantrymen from the 101st which David served in and so many others who took their own lives. And because “Taps” is played at every one of their memorials the tune always brings back the cumulative loss we feel from all those that have died.

We've attended dozens of funerals and memorial services to mourn friends and colleagues like Stu killed by a rocket in the Green Zone; Pat Joe Phil and Blaine who were killed while preparing for deployment; Devon and Andy who were killed on a peacekeeping mission in Kosovo.

This haunting tune started during the Civil War as a bugle call to signal end of day replacing three taps of the drum that had signaled lights out. Soon after it was played at its first military funeral because it was safer than the traditional firing of three rifle volleys.
Whether we would have gone to a parade a cemetery or a private ceremony there is one thing that would surely be playing at every event this weekend: the playing of “Taps.”
